name: Minuteman Missile National Historic Site
description: During the Cold War, a vast arsenal of nuclear missiles were placed in the Great Plains. Hidden in plain sight, for thirty years 1,000 missiles were kept on constant alert; hundreds remain today. The Minuteman Missile remains an iconic weapon in the American nuclear arsenal. It holds the power to destroy civilization, but is meant as a nuclear deterrent to maintain peace and prevent war.
shortDescription: During the Cold War, a vast arsenal of nuclear missiles were placed in the Great Plains. Hidden in plain sight, for thirty years 1,000 missiles were kept on constant alert; hundreds remain today. The ...

operatingHours.description:
Visitors are invited to go inside the fenced compound and look down into the silo at a Minuteman missile in its historic state, protected by a glass viewing enclosure. A narrated ranger guided tour of Delta-09 is available year-round using your cell phone. Inclement weather may close this site on occasion.

***Please Be Aware***
The park will NOT be changing days of operation. The park will be open Tuesday-Saturday through the summer and winter seasons.

climate.weatherDescription: Rapid weather changes are common in the western South Dakota area where Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is located. Variations from season to season and from year to year are great. Characteristics of the climate are hot dry summers and bitterly cold winters. Wind is a constant on the Great Plains, winds in excess of 50 mph not uncommon. During the winter season, winds typically blow from the north-northwest and have been known to cause wind chills in excess of -40 degrees.

images.title: Delta-09 enclosure
images.altText: Glass structure over the silo allows visitors to look down at the missile
images.caption: The glass enclosure allows visitors to view a Minuteman II missile in the silo.

images.title: Minuteman II Missile
images.altText: A cylindrical missile inside an underground silo.
images.caption: A Minuteman II nuclear missile remains on alert, representing the 1,000 missiles which kept a constant vigil during the Cold War.

images.title: A winter visit to Delta-09
images.altText: Two people are visible at the missile silo through a chain link fence
images.caption: A visit to the Delta-09 missile silo allows the opportunity to consider the role of these missile in America's defense during the Cold War.

images.title: Delta-01
images.altText: A brown building behind a tall fence with warning signs
images.caption: For thirty years, US Air Force staff monitored a flight of ten nuclear missiles at the Delta-01 Launch Control Facility.

images.title: "Thirty Minutes or Less"
images.altText: A large metal blast door with art of a Domino with a nuclear missile
images.caption: Behind this blast door is the control center where two missileers kept a constant watch over ten nuclear missiles.

images.title: Morale Art of the Cold War
images.altText: A painting of a nuclear missile bursting through a Soviet Flag
images.caption: Located next to the elevator, this painting served as a reminder to missileers who they were defending the United States against.

images.title: Nose-to-Nose with Armegeddon
images.altText: View down a silo at a nuclear missile
images.caption: Visitors can peer through the glass at a Minuteman II missile in the silo at Delta-09.

images.title: Night view of Delta-09
images.altText: Night view of the Delta-09 site
images.caption: Night view of the Delta-09 site

images.title: Minuteman Missile Visitor Center
images.altText: A modern building with a prominent glass clerestory dominates a prairie landscape at sunset
images.caption: The visitor center at sunset.

images.title: Cold War "Blast Door" art at Delta-01
images.altText: A view of a concrete wall with a painting and a blastdoor with art
images.caption: Morale art reminded missile officers who the enemy was during the Cold War
